[Wolle ?e nou ihere wordes swiÃ¾e gode] Wolle ?e nou ihere wordes swiÃ¾e gode Of one patriarke after Noees flode? Nellic ?ou nou?t tellen of Ã¾is flodes grame, Bote of one patriarke, Iacob was his name. While men loueden meri song, gamen & feire tale; Nou hem is wel leuere gon to Ã¾e nale, Vcchen out Ã¾e gurdel & rume Ã¾e wombe, Comen erliche Ã¾ider & sitte Ã¾er ful longe. Ãat is Ã¾e soule ful loÃ¾, & lef Ã¾e licame, Bote we hit bileuen, hit biÃ¾ a luÃ¾er game. To fullen oure wombe hit is lutel pris, & seÃ¾Ã¾e ligge slepe, such hit were a gris. Ãus ferden oure aldren bi Noees dawe, Of mete & of drinke hi fulden here mawe; & for ?iuernesse Ã¾ei weren ri?t wod; For Ã¾i sende oure Louerd Noees flod. Ão hi mi?ten drinke Ã¾at hi weren fulle, Hi floten swiÃ¾e riued bi dich & bi pulle. Ãer nas in Ã¾is world hul non so hei?, Ãat tis vnirude flod muchel ne ouerstei?. Nou ich wole fon on Ã¾er ich er let, & tellen ou of Iacob, so ich ?ou bihet. Iacob liuede in londe & louede Godes lawe So dude Ysaac his fader bi his lifdawe. Iacob liuede in londe, & feire he ladde his lif, Sones he wan ten on Lya his wif; On Rachel he wan tweye, Iosep & Beniamin. Betere is for to here Ã¾is tale Ã¾en to drinke win; For whoso hereÃ¾ Ã¾is tale to Ã¾e nendinge, Of more reufule song herde he neuere singe. Nou he sit in halle, Iacob Ã¾e elde man, & his sones alle from felde comeÃ¾ hom. Iacob bihalt his sones, of hem he was bliÃ¾e; & Iosep Ã¾e ?unge bigan to speke swiÃ¾e. His fader he tolde a swefne ani?t Ã¾at him mette & bad swiÃ¾e ?erne telle Ã¾at me him lette. âDo nou, mi sone dere, God leue Ã¾e so to speke, Ãat tou in none worde his heste ne tobreke.â âVader,â seide Iosep, ânou ich wole Ã¾e telle Of mine metinge & of mine spelle. Me Ã¾u?te, ase ich slepte, afeld Ã¾at we were, Ãou & mi moder & mine breÃ¾ren here; & so we repen oure corn & oure sseues knetten, & vpri?t in Ã¾e felde wel feire we hem setten, Me Ã¾u?te Ã¾at ?oure sseues, Ã¾er hi stoden alle, To me Ã¾ei gonnen louten & to mi fet falle. ?it me Ã¾u?te an oÃ¾er, fader, God hit wot, Ãat te sunne & Ã¾e mone fellen to mi fot. ?it me Ã¾u?te Ã¾e Ã¾ridde, fader, telli Ã¾e, Ãat elleue sterren to fote fellen me. Ãis is mi sweuene, fader, Ã¾at ich telle Ã¾e, ?if hit Ã¾i wille were, ared what hit mai be.â Ãenne seide Iacob to Iosep his sone, âTide wat bitide, ?it wole Ã¾i swefne come. Tide wat bitide, ?it wole Ã¾i swefne be. Ich wene mid iwisse, ?ut we hit ssulen ise, Ãat ich & Ã¾i moder & Ã¾ine breÃ¾ren ek Moten for fine nede comen to Ã¾ine fet.â Ãis iherden his breÃ¾ren, Ã¾erfore hem was ful wo, Hi gonnen hatie Iosep ase here fulle fo. Ãau alle his ten breÃ¾ren Ã¾erfore hateden hine, Ãat oure Louerd wole habben ido mai no man binime Ãis breÃ¾ren wendeÃ¾ afeld to witen here fe, Ac Iosep leuede at hom, Ã¾at hende was & fre. Iacob sit in halle & clepeÃ¾ Iosep his sone; Ãat child swiÃ¾e sone to his fader is icome. At his fader fot Ã¾at child him sit akne, & axeÃ¾ him wel feire wat his wille be. Sone seide Iacob, âWende Ã¾ou most afeld To seche Ã¾ine breÃ¾ren, & wer be here teld. Bring vs hom tiding hu Ã¾ine breÃ¾ren fare. Vre Louerd, Ã¾at is in heuene, berewe Ã¾e from care.â Iosep geÃ¾ afeldward, euel ne Ã¾ou?te he non, He wende to sechen his breÃ¾ren, & sou?te his fulle fon. He secheÃ¾ hem, ne mai he hem finde, Ã¾erfore him was wo; Ãenne fond a man al one Ã¾e child wondrinde go. Ãis man axede Ã¾at child woder he wolde te; Iosep his breÃ¾ren secheÃ¾ & fain hem wolde ise. Ãe man onswerede Ã¾at child, & Ã¾us he spac to him, âHi beÃ¾ in one felde, hatte Dotaym; Ac lutel er hi weren in Sichem, bi hem ich stod Ã¾o. Child, ?if Ã¾ou hem wolt finde, to Dotaym Ã¾u go. Child, ?if Ã¾ou hem wolt finde, to Dotaym Ã¾u go ri?t, Also ich vnderstonde, Ã¾er Ã¾u hem finde mi?t.â Iosep mid gode wille Ã¾iderward he geÃ¾, Ãer alle hise ten breÃ¾ren habbeÃ¾ isworen his deÃ¾. He cam toward his breÃ¾ren, Ã¾at ternde ssolde bere, Hi siggeÃ¾ hem bitwene, âHer comeÃ¾ Ã¾e metere. Nime we & quellen Ã¾is ilke hinderling, & lokeÃ¾ wat him ssal helpe Ã¾erafter his meting.â He cam to his breÃ¾ren & grettem eueruchon; Hi Ã¾encheÃ¾ al an oÃ¾er, & gripeÃ¾ him anon. Quellen him hi wolleÃ¾, nou hi him habbeÃ¾ inome, Ac Ruben, Ã¾at o broÃ¾er, he spac atte frome, âA dep pet is her bisides Ã¾at water er Ã¾is in stod; WorpeÃ¾ Ã¾erinne Iosep, ssende we nou?t oure blod,â (Iosep for to helpe Ruben spac Ã¾is tale) â?if we Ã¾is child aquelleÃ¾, hit beÃ¾ oure fader bale.â His fader him ?af a kurtel Ã¾at rum was & wid, Wel hit bicam Ã¾e child, hit was him fotsid. Hi strupten of Ã¾e curtel, of swere & of chin, Al naked in Ã¾e pette hi worpen Ã¾at child in. Ac Ruben, Ã¾at o broÃ¾er, Ã¾enne he is igo, Ne mi?te he for reuÃ¾e atte pette be Ã¾o. Ãis oÃ¾re sitteÃ¾ bisides & foÃ¾ on here mete, ÃencheÃ¾ hi neiÃ¾er of serewe ne of hete. Iosep sit in pette mid ful sori mod, His breÃ¾ren law?eÃ¾ loude, Ã¾at gamen hem Ã¾inkeÃ¾ god. Nou Iosep sit in pette & wringeÃ¾ his honde. A wey, Ã¾at bitwene breÃ¾ren ssal be Ã¾us muchel onde! Nou drawen him vp hi wolleÃ¾, & quellen him atte frome, Ãenne seien hi bisides twei riche chapmen come. Vrom a lond hi comen, Galaad ihoten is, Mid here assen isemed of fer & of gris. Of stor & of spices Ã¾ei ladden grete male Into Egipte lond to sullen hit to sale. Ãenne spac him Iuda, he spac atte frome, âWolle we sullen Iosep Ã¾is chapmen Ã¾at here come? Fer into Egypte lond hi him wolleÃ¾ lede, Ãenne worÃ¾ his sweuen eÃ¾ to arede.â Hi comen to Ã¾is chapmen & sseweden here tale, Iosep in Ã¾e pette hi chepeden to sale. Ãis chapmen beÃ¾ wise & axeÃ¾ wer he be. âComeÃ¾ ner,â hi seiden, â& ?e him mowen ise; Hit is a swiÃ¾e feir child & of kunne hei?.â Mid Ã¾at ilke worde Ã¾e pet hi weren nei?. Hi drowen vp Iosep mid one longe rope, Ac one gode while ne mi?te he speke for wope. Ãis chapmen biholdeÃ¾ Iosep, Ã¾at beÃ¾ swiÃ¾e wis, & Iosep to begge swiÃ¾e lef hem is. Hi chepeÃ¾ & hi bedeÃ¾, sone hi beÃ¾ at on. Iosep wrang his honden & was ful sori man. Hi casten hond to purse, Ã¾e panes beÃ¾ itold; Nou helpe Crist Iosep, so ?ung he is isold. Ãis chapmen fengeÃ¾ Ã¾at child, Ã¾is breÃ¾ren Ã¾at fe; Darf no man axe wer Iosep sori be; For euere ase hi hine ledeÃ¾, euer he wepeÃ¾, His fader & his moder ?ung he forleteÃ¾. Ãis chapmen beÃ¾ wel bliÃ¾e Ã¾at Iosep habbeÃ¾ ibou?t, & vpon Ã¾e sestronde hi him habbeÃ¾ ibrou?t. Ãis chapmen nimeÃ¾ Iosep ri?t bi Ã¾e hond, & so hi ledeÃ¾ Iosep into Egipte lond. Ac of Egiptene speche couÃ¾e he no Ã¾ing, For Ã¾i he wepte sore, Ã¾is ilke ?ungling. Hi ladden Iosep into Ã¾e bur?, Ã¾at riche was & strong: Castles heie & proute, stretes wide & long, Mani feir halle & mani feir bour, Whit so eni lilie, bri?t so eni flour. Muche was Ã¾e blisse Ã¾at was in Ã¾e bur?, Iosep for to sullen hi ladden Ã¾ur? & Ã¾ur?. Ãider comen kni?tes & burgeis ful bolde, Hi comen into Ã¾e strete Iosep to biholde. Leuedis of boure & maidenes fre Comen into Ã¾e strete Iosep to ise. Ac Ã¾er Ã¾u?te muche wonder mani a moder sone, Hem Ã¾u?te hit was an angel from heuene icome. Ful sone Ã¾e tiding of Iosep hit sprong To Putifar Ã¾e stiward of Egipte lond. Putifar Ã¾e stiward Ã¾ider he is icome, & in his ferade mani a kni?tes sone. So sone so Ã¾e stiward on Iosep bihuld, He li?te of his stede, his mantel he vnfuld, Cofre he lette vnlouke & gold casten out anon, Sone he bou?te Iosep of Ã¾is chapmon. More Ã¾en he axede for Iosep he ?af, & seÃ¾Ã¾en on his stede wel feire he him haf. Nou lete we Iosep ride, God ssilde him from care, & vte we speken of Iacob his fader, hou he fare. Nou he sit in halle, Iacob Ã¾e elde man, & his sones ten from felde comeÃ¾ hom, & Ioseppes curtel hi bringeÃ¾ al blodi, Ão Iacob hit gan biholde iwis he was sori. Ão he sau? his kurtel ispreind al wiÃ¾ blod, Nas neuere for his child fader so sorimod. Adoun he fel iswowe & tar his hore loc, Ãe moder feng to renden hire neb & hire smoc. Euer seide Ã¾e moder, âWo is me a liue, For mi sone Iosep be ich neuere bliÃ¾e.â Euere seide Iacob, âIosep is islawe, OÃ¾er summe luÃ¾ere deres habbeÃ¾ him todrawe.â Ãider comen manie of fremede & o kinne For to gladen Iacob, ac his sones hadden sinne. Woso seye Iacob his sorinesse lede, Hit were muche reuÃ¾e in boc for to rede. Nou Iacob sit in halle & wringeÃ¾ his honde, We ssule speken of Iosep in Egipte londe. Nou Putifar ssrudeÃ¾ Iosep mid dereworÃ¾e ssroud, & ?iueÃ¾ him Pharaon Ã¾e king, mid him he is proud. Nou is Iosep feir child in Pharaones halle, Ãe pore & Ã¾e riche louieÃ¾ him alle. Tofore Ã¾e king selue he serueÃ¾ atte bord, Of pore & of riche he haÃ¾ wel god word. Hit fel in one daye, Ã¾e king was out iwent To Ã¾e wode to ssete mid his bowe ibent. Ãe quene louede Iosep ase hir owe lif, Heo sente him after sone to speken hire wiÃ¾. Ac of Ã¾isse Ã¾inge nuste Iosep ri?t nou?t: Aru? hit were to knowe alle wimmanes Ã¾ou?t. Ac Ã¾er wimman is god, nis non so swete Ã¾ing, For al Ã¾at euere Eue brac in paradis Oure leuedi hit bette, Ã¾at dereworÃ¾est is. Iosep cam to boure, Ã¾at hende was & fre. âLeuedi,â quod Iosep, âwat Ã¾i wille be?â âIosep,â quod Ã¾e quene, ânou Ã¾ou art welcome, Nou in mine boure ich Ã¾e haue inome. Ich Ã¾e wole tellen one tidinge, Ich wole Ã¾e make richest man after oure kinge. Ãou ssalt habbe Ã¾i wil of fer & of gris, Of gold & of seluer, of al Ã¾at feir is. Ãou ssalt haue Ã¾i wil of al Egipte londe, Ssal neuere no man Ã¾ine heste astonde. & of one Ã¾inge iwis Ã¾u mi?t be bliÃ¾e, Ãer nis no man me so lef Ã¾at euere is aliue. ?if Ã¾ou canst in boure louie me derne, Ãe prute of Egipte ssal Ã¾e nou?t be werne.â Mid Ã¾at ilke worde heo gan him cluppe & kisse. âIosep, ich am Ã¾in,â heo seide, âmid iwisse.â Iosep of Ã¾ese wordes nas he no Ã¾ing glad, He nolde in none wise don ase Ã¾e quene him bad. Ãei? Iosep were in boure stille bisteke, He nolde in none wise his trouÃ¾e tobreke. Mid his white fingres hire armes he vnfeld, & wende from Ã¾e quene, ac his mantel heo athuld. Heo braid of hire wimpel & loude feng to reme, Ãer come serians wel fele for to nime ?eme, Wat here leuedi mi?te be, Ã¾at hem was so lef. âA! LokeÃ¾ nou,â heo seide, âÃ¾is Ebrewisse Ã¾ef, Of me he wende stille to habben his gome, Nas neuere quene in Ã¾is lond ido so muche ssome.â Ãe king cam from Ã¾e wode mid blowinde beme, Ãe quene fel to his fet & loude feng to reme, & tolde Ã¾e king of Ã¾is muchele ssome, Ãunche hit no wonder Ã¾ei? he ne hadde grome. Ãe king him lette nime & ful faste binde: Nou ne mai Iosep nenne frend finde. Alle Ã¾at Ã¾is iherde Ã¾erfore weren ful wo: Summe for Ã¾e quene, ac for Iosep wel mo. Nou is Iosep so wo Ã¾at he not wat he mai: Bide neuere no god man non so sori dai. Ac heuede Iosep ido ase Ã¾e quene him bad, He mi?te ben in halle mid oÃ¾re bliÃ¾e & glad. Gulteles in Ã¾e pette his breÃ¾ren hine dude, & gulteles he is nouÃ¾e in ful Ã¾estri stede. Ac Ã¾er he is ful longe muche wo to abide, Oure Louerd he hit Ã¾onkeÃ¾, tide wat bitide. Hit fel in one daye to Ã¾e newe ?er, Iwreyed was wel stronge Ã¾e kinges botiler, & Ã¾e kinges baxtere iwreyed was ful stronge. To Iosep hi beÃ¾ icast, & Ã¾er hi liggeÃ¾ longe, & in Ã¾e prison liggeÃ¾ mid ful muchel wronge. NabbeÃ¾ hi none blisse of harpe ne of songe, Of olde ne of ?unge, of fremede ne of sibbe, Leuere hem were to be ded Ã¾en so longe to libbe. Hit fel in one ni?te Ã¾e botiler feng to slepe, A swiÃ¾e muri sweuene him Ã¾u?te Ã¾at he gan mete, Ãat in Ã¾e win?arde Ã¾e kinges coupe he ber, & wrong hit of Ã¾e grapes ful of win cler. Ãe baxtere mette an oÃ¾er, nas hit nou?t so god, In Ã¾e bachuse him Ã¾u?te Ã¾at he stod, Of bred he fulde a basket & to Ã¾e halle he wolde hit bere, Ãe foules bi Ã¾e lifte hit gonnen al totere. Amorewen ase Ã¾ei seten wiÃ¾ Iosep atte bord, Here sweuen hi him tolden word after word. Iosep here sweuen sone haueÃ¾ arou?t. â?e ssulen in Ã¾is Ã¾ridde dai of prison ben ibrou?t. Ãou ssalt, sire botiler, Ã¾i mester vnderfonge, WiÃ¾ alle worssipe mest Ã¾e king serue longe. & wen me serueÃ¾ Ã¾e king mid harpe & mid songe, Ãench on seli Iosep, Ã¾at her liÃ¾ mid wronge.â Also ase Iosep seide, also hit bicam: Ãe botiler of Iosep lute ?eme nam, Ãat in Ã¾e prison liÃ¾ mid ful muche wronge. Wel ou?te we to heren him Ã¾at is ri?twis, & nou ?e mowen ihere hou hende oure Louerd is, Hou feire he sende help to Iosep Ã¾e ?ungling Ãur? a sweuene Ã¾at mette Pharaon Ã¾e king. Ãe king ase he slepte him Ã¾u?te Ã¾at he rod In a medewe grene Ã¾at long was & brod. Seue kuin fatte him Ã¾u?te Ã¾at he sau? gon: So fatte ne so feire sau? he neuere non. OÃ¾er seue lene to?eines hem gonne gon & frete Ã¾e seue fatte kyn eueruchon. Ão Ã¾e seue fatte kin alle forswolewed were, Ãe seue kin lene neuere Ã¾e fullore nere. Amorewen Ã¾e king awoc, his sweuen he tolde Vrles & barons & burgeis ful bolde. Ac Ã¾er nas neiÃ¾er baron ne kni?t Ãat of Ã¾isse Ã¾inge couÃ¾e reden him aiwi?t. He cam to Ã¾e kinge & tolde him anon Of him & of Ã¾e baxtere hou hit was igon. âLouerd, of Ã¾i sweuene ?if he ne seiÃ¾ Ã¾en ende, Do me, Louerd, a?ein into Ã¾ine bende.â Ãenne seide Faraon, Faraon Ã¾e king, âLet bringe bifore me Ã¾ene ?ungling. ?if he of mi sweuene seiÃ¾ me Ã¾en ende, Al his gult ich him for?iue & quite faten of bende.â ForÃ¾ me feccheÃ¾ Iosep, Ã¾at bloc was & lene, Durste for Ã¾e quene no man him bimene. âLouerd,â seide Iosep, âich hit Ã¾onke Ã¾e, Nou ich wot mid iwisse islawe Ã¾at ich ssal be, Nou ich wot mid iwisse Ã¾at ich ssal ben islawe, For nabbi none blisse of mi lifdawe.â Ac Ã¾e king wel feire his sweuen he tolde, & bad swiÃ¾e feire reden Ã¾at he hit ssolde. âLouerd,â seide Iosep, âÃ¾i sweuen is eÃ¾ to telle, Oure Louerd wole in Ã¾i lond muche prude felle. Ãis is Ã¾i sweuene, sire king, Ã¾ench Ã¾ou Ã¾eron, Bote Crist be Ã¾in help, Egipte is al agon.â Heron Ã¾e king Ã¾encheÃ¾ bi ni?t & bi dai, Not he a liue what he do mai. Heron Ã¾e king Ã¾encheÃ¾ bi dai & bi ni?t, Me ne couÃ¾e of Ã¾is Ã¾inge reden him no wi?t. Ãenne spac an old man Ã¾at was wis of speche. Wenne ich Ã¾enche on Abraham, hou he gan Ã¾ider wende: Muche Ã¾o Ã¾olede Abraham ssame mid his wiue, & seÃ¾Ã¾en atte nende of lond me gan him driue. & wenne Ã¾e ri?twise man Ã¾olede such ssome, Into Egipte to sende Ã¾uncheÃ¾ me no gome. Ofte of Ã¾is smal chaf Ã¾is breÃ¾ren brou?ten hom, & for wone of mete maden muche mon. Beniamin Ã¾e ?unge bad his moder bred, & seide he was afingred Ã¾at he was nei? ded. Ãe moder swor swiÃ¾e Ã¾at bred nadda non, Ão wrong he his honden, Iacob Ã¾e elde man, For leuere were Iacob of liue for to ben Ãen bi Beniamin Ã¾e ?unge Ã¾ese pines isen. ?it Beniamin Ã¾e ?unge makeÃ¾ muche mon Ãenne clepede Iacob his sones eueruchon. âSones,â seide Iacob, âNede ?e mote wende For to sech vs corn in Ã¾issen estende. For betere ?ou is to swinke & erne ?oure mete Ãenne at hom to deye on hunger & on hete. NimeÃ¾ ?oure assen & nimeÃ¾ ?oure horn, NimeÃ¾ ?ou seluer & gold to buggen vs corn. Ac Beniamin Ã¾e ?unge bileue ssal at hom; Me reweÃ¾ euere Iosep Ã¾at afelde was igon. For ?if he hadde at hom bileued, ?it he were aliue; For Ã¾e loue of Iosep be ich neuere bliÃ¾e. NimeÃ¾ ?oure wepnen & wendeÃ¾ ?oure wai, Berewe ?ou from care oure Louerd, Ã¾at wel mai.â Feire fareÃ¾ Ã¾is ?unge men bi dai & bi ni?t Into Egipte lond Ã¾at hi comen ri?t. Muche was Ã¾e blisse & muche was Ã¾e gome In water & in londe of wilde & of tome. Muche was Ã¾e blisse Ã¾at hi Ã¾ar iseye, Bernes ful riche & mowen ful heye. Muche was Ã¾e blisse after here swinke Ãat hi Ã¾are funden of mete & of drinke. Hem oftok a menestral, his harpe he bar arugge. âWhennes be ?e, ?unge men? Ich bidde Ã¾at ?e me sigge. Ãar Ã¾e hendeste man Ã¾at euere is aliue ?ou wole gistni toni?t & make ?ou ful bliÃ¾e. ?e Ã¾uncheÃ¾ ferrene men & alle freboren, Toni?t ssal mani kni?tchild knele ?ou biforen.â He brou?tem to Ã¾e castel ase he hem bihet, & spac wiÃ¾ Ã¾e porter in Ã¾at he hem let. Hi seyen in Ã¾e castel mani riche Ã¾ing, & Iosep sitten in halle, such hit were a king. Ac if hi wenden Iosep Ã¾er for to sen, Leuere hem were alle at hom on hunger ded to ben. Alle Ã¾ese ten breÃ¾ren comen into Ã¾e halle, Tofore Ioseppes fet akne hi valleÃ¾ alle. âAriseÃ¾ vpâ, seide Iosep, âSitte ?e nou?t akne, Ac telleÃ¾ me wel feire wat ?oure wille be.â âFrom Ierusalemâ, quod Ruben, âwe beÃ¾ hider icome. Let sullen vs corn, louerd, for Godes loue Old man is oure fader & corn naÃ¾ he non, For muchel one nede we beÃ¾ hider igon.â Ãenne seide Iosep, such hit were his gome, âWat isâ, he seide, â?oure faderes nome?â âVre fader hei?te Iacob, vre moder Rachel.â Mid Ã¾at ilke worde he knew hem ful wel. Ão Iosep iherde Ã¾at his fader was aliue, Nas neuere for his fader child also bliÃ¾e. He goÃ¾ into Ã¾e boure & wepeÃ¾ for blisse, Sore he is alonged his breÃ¾ren to kisse. Iosep cam into halle, Ã¾e water he lette bringe, & halde to here honden mid his wite vingres. Feire beÃ¾ Ã¾is ?unge men iserued Ã¾ilke ni?t Of mete ne of drinke trukede hem no wi?t. Iosep ful riche win lette to him bringe, & so he bad Ã¾is children on Ebrewisse singe. & so hi sungen alle ase Iosep hem bad, SeÃ¾Ã¾e he cam into Egipte nas Iosep so glad. Al of rede wete here assen he lette seme, For to meten here corn nam he none ?eme. Nou dude Iosep a swiÃ¾e wonderÃ¾ing, He nam a guldene nap, was Pharaones Ã¾e king, & putte in Ã¾ones sakke wiÃ¾inne Ã¾e prene, & Ã¾erof cam Ã¾is ?unge men swiÃ¾e muche tene. Feire hi nomen leue to wenden here way Toward here contre a lutel ere day.
